metadata.title: Amputation, Upper Extremity, in Adults  Physical Therapy
synonyms: upper extremity amputation in adults  physical therapy
upper limb amputation in adults: physical therapy
anatomical location body part affected: Upper extremity; parts affected depend on level of amputation, from fingertip to the entire arm, scapula, and clavicle
description: The removal of all or part of the upper extremity
Amputations of the upper limb are much less frequent than amputations of the lower limb and are usually due to trauma(3,5)

Based on their level, they can be categorized into the following types:(3) –Shoulder disarticulation and interscapulothoracic or forequarter amputation -Both are rare amputations, usually a result of cancer or severe trauma -In an interscapulothoracic or forequarter amputation, the upper extremity (UE), scapula, and clavicle are removed -In a shoulder disarticulation, the amputation is through the shoulder joint -A disarticulation is an amputation through a joint,(1,2) without cutting the bone -In a true shoulder disarticulation, the humeral head is removed -A modified shoulder amputation may be performed through the surgical neck of the humerus to preserve the humeral head -If the humeral head can be saved, the shape of the shoulder can be maintained, allowing for a more natural-looking  shoulder contour –Transhumeral amputation -Removal of any portion of the humerus -With this amputation, preservation of bone length is important for function and prosthesis use -A long humeral stump preserves some functional shoulder internal and external rotation, which is lost with a short stump(4) -A postoperative prosthesis may be utilized directly after surgery –Elbow disarticulation -Removal of the forearm at the elbow -Allows rotation of the humerus while utilizing a prosthesis –Transradial amputation -Amputation through the radius and ulna bones while maintaining the elbow joint -A long transradial amputation preserves some supination and pronation; all is lost with a short amputation(4) -Forearm rotation and strength can be preserved  -Krukenberg procedure(17) -The stump of the transradial amputation (which includes the radius and ulna) is surgically converted into a claw-like pincer with preserved dexterity and tactile sensation -Surgery is performed as a secondary operation after a transradial amputation -These digits may allow for functional use of the UE during grasp and release tasks with self-care,  leisure, and work tasks -A conventional prosthesis can be worn over the Krukenberg forearm and myoelectric devices can be adapted to use the forearm motion -Best suited for patients who are blind, because they do not have the visual input necessary to operate prosthetic devices effectively –Wrist disarticulation -Candidates are reportedly good prosthetic users as this amputation maintains function of the distal radioulnar joint for forearm rotation -Wrist disarticulation is controversial. Opponents argue that fitting with a prosthesis is more complicated than a transradial amputation, whereas proponents cite preserved forearm rotation (wrist disarticulation results in preservation of about 50% of pronation and supination)(4) –Carpus amputation –Partial hand amputation -Thumb amputation -As the thumb is highly significant for overall hand function, loss of hand function may occur -If the amputation is at or beyond the most distal thumb joint, hand function may be preserved -Amputation at the metacarpophalangeal joint can be disastrous to hand function; other surgical procedures may be required to enhance hand performance -Hypersensitivity and inability to tolerate cold may occur at the residual digit -Digit amputation -Amputations distal to the insertion of the flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS) allow for continued movement in flexion -Amputations proximal to the FDS tendon insertion maintain use of the residual stump in grasping tasks (e.g., metacarpophalangeal [MCP]flexion via lumbricals) -Middle finger amputations often make maintaining a grasp of small items a challenge, as the items may drop through the space created in the hand by the amputation -Fingertip amputation -Reportedly the most common type of UE amputation -Complications may occur such as phantom limb pain, hypersensitivity, and an inability to tolerate cold

reimbursement: Patient may have ongoing legal and/or worker’s compensation claims

Advances in UE prostheses over the past decade have resulted in new technologies and many prosthetic options. Because of their newness, there is a lack of evidence to direct their prescription and training, which can interfere with timely reimbursement authorization(11)

The small number of UE prostheses that are fitted in comparison with lower limb prostheses(approximately 15:1) makes it difficult to meet the demands of third-party  payers for objective, statistically significant data to support the utilization of newer UE prostheses
Thorough documentation of clinical outcomes is useful to justify reimbursement

A more expensive prosthesis (e.g., myoelectric) may not be approved unless specific criteria are met, such as adequate cognitive ability to operate the prosthesis, adequate remaining musculature, and when a less technologically advanced device cannot meet the needs of the patient to perform ADLs
presentation signs and symptoms: The patient may present with the following signs and symptoms after an UE amputation: –Discomfort secondary to surgery or prosthesis(2) –Swelling(4) –Scar tissue adhesions(4) –Phantom limb pain and sensation(2) -Please see  Clinical Review ... Phantom Limb Pain  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708996 for more detail –Hyperesthesia(4) –Loss of sensation(4) –Reduced tolerance to prosthesis(2) –Skin ulcers or breakdown(2) –Impaired ROM(4) –Decreased independence in ADLs/IADLs(2) –Overuse injuries in unaffected UE(2) –Emotional issues regarding loss of limb related to self-image(4) -There may be cultural differences with regard to the impact of the amputation on self-esteem  and self-image Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Joint and limb positioning in a pain-free  position is optimal during evaluation
With changes in positioning, use slow transitions to prevent dizziness or fainting post-surgery

causes: Trauma–90% of UE amputations are related to trauma(5,25)–Common causes of trauma necessitating amputation-Accidents involving power tools and machinery(2)-Combat-related  injuries(5)–Traumatic injuries that result in a limb becoming “mangled,”which is defined as a limb that is unrecognizable due tocutting, tearing, or crushing, may result in amputation if limb salvage is not possible(13)

Other severe diseases or conditions that may lead to amputation–Peripheral vascular disease, diabetes, and frostbite(3)–Chemical, thermal, or electrical burns(2)–Lack of function(3)–Congenital deformity(4)
pathogenesis: If there is a congenital deformity present, amputation may be recommended at any time if this is believed to provide thepatient with improved function

Trauma–Amputation is indicated with:(3)-loss of blood flow to a region of the UE (or entire UE) and surgical correction of vascular structures is not possible; thissituation is deemed an absolute indication-crush injuries due to the dispersion of cell toxins and myoglobin, thereby raising the risk of kidney failure, respiratorydistress syndrome, and death; high-risk  patients (those with multiple injuries and those advanced in age) typically arenot candidates for limb salvage–Early amputation has replaced limb preservation techniques in an effort to reduce emotional and financial losses thattypically followed an unsuccessful attempt at limb preservation(3)

Cancer–The surgical margin is painstakingly thought out, as the impact is significant on function as well as the disease processitself(3)-Intralesional margin – at least part of the incision crosses the tumor site-Marginal margin – the incision goes into the inflammatory zone (around the tumor) but not into the tumor itself-Wide margin – the incision does not go into the inflammatory zone or tumor; however, the incision does stay within theanatomic region of the tumor-Radical margin – the incision is out of the anatomic region of the tumor (e.g., incision is at shoulder and tumor is in theelbow)
risk factors: Among all individuals with UE amputations, > 75% are men(5)
Those who work with power tools and machinery are more at risk for traumatic injury(4) and therefore at greater risk foramputation

overall contraindications precautions: Carefully follow surgeon’s orders and restrictions
Instruct the patient on proper positioning to avoid contractures(2)
The patient’s and family’s emotional state must be taken into account during the evaluation and subsequent treatment
Emotional support may be required due to poor body image and/or depression(2)

With regard to use of prosthetic devices and postsurgical interventions, skin breakdown and open wounds may result, so universal precautions should always be utilized when touching and mobilizing the stump or limb during ADLs or therapeutic exercise(2)

As sensory impairments and phantom limb pain/sensation may occur after surgery,(4) precautions should be in place to assist with sensory deficits. Please refer to the treatment section for more information
Scar tissue may form which may lead to pain during a muscle contraction or when utilizing a prosthetic device(2)
Patients with an UE amputation are at risk for repetitive stress injury in both UEs due to overuse and require monitoring of their activity level to avoid further injury(2,16)
Because balance may be impaired following amputation, the patient may be at risk for falls; please refer to the specific fall-prevention  program of the facility for the individual patient
Monitor for signs of new or worsening infection and notify physician
Monitor for signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Joint and limb positioning in a pain-free  position is optimal during evaluation
With changes in positioning, use slow transitions to prevent dizziness or fainting post-surgery

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -What contributing factors such as traumatic event or disease led to the decision to amputate? Is this a new amputation? Is this a revision of a prior amputation?

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management Medical management will vary depending on the type of amputation and the symptoms the patient is describing When planning for amputation, preserving bone length if possible is the main priority(2) to allow for optimal function A coordinated rehabilitation team is beneficial during preoperative planning and postoperative care(2) If a traumatic amputation, describe any concurrent injuries and their treatment and progress. Have there been any complications? If due to cancer, describe disease treatment, including chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy
course of treatment.medications: The following medications may be prescribed;(2) inquire if patient is taking them and if they are effectively controlling symptoms Tricyclic antidepressants and antiepileptics Beta blockers for phantom pain Opiates for long-term  pain In the immediate postoperative stage, a patient-controlled  analgesia (PCA) pump typically is used After the PCA is discontinued, long-acting opioids are used Antibiotics for infection NSAIDs
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition are the following:(2)
X-ray  to evaluate for osteomyelitis, heterotopic ossification, or bone spurs that may impact prosthetic wear
Electrodiagnostic testing may determine presence of peripheral neuropathy
Electrodiagnostic testing to determine potential for myoelectric use
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture, hypnosis, biofeedback) and whether they help In a case study describing the use of acupuncture for phantom limb pain, a 35-year-old male patient with left shoulder disarticulation who was experiencing significant phantom limb pain (9/10 on V AS) had significant decrease in pain (to 4/10) after 3 acupuncture treatments(19)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Ask the patient if he or she has determined what worsens or alleviates identified symptoms
history of present illness.body chart: If applicable, use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: What current symptoms is patient reporting that may be interfering with function? Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, throbbing, aching, burning, numbness, tingling, squeezing,  pinching, or cramping). Following surgery, it may initially be challenging to determine whether a patient’s pain is in the residual limb or is phantom pain. Phantom pain usually is intermittent, although some patients have continuous pain with superimposed exacerbations.(12) Inquire about other phantom sensations that may be annoying but not necessarily painful, including itching, pressure, touch, and movement
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much )
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also, document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition, symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician, and symptoms related to comorbidities or concomitant traumatic injuriesDocument the presence of any psychosocial issues; patients with amputations may experience various psychological reactions such as shock, grief, anger, denial, helplessness, and depression(14)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Does patient require supplemental oxygen? Does patient become short of breath with exercise? Was patient intubated at any point in his or her recovery? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Previous amputation? Previous upper limb injury or dysfunction? Did patient undergo previous attempts at treatment to avoid amputation, such as bypass surgery or limb salvage surgery? The decision of salvage versus amputation in the UE is based on the likelihood of retaining some useful function even if the function is minimal. Even a severely compromised arm may function as an assistive limb. An assistive UE often functions better than currently available prostheses(3)
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: What are the patient’s interests at home? What are the patient’s occupations and roles? Is the patient employed? What is the nature of the work? Is he or she planning on returning to the workforce? Does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: What was prior hand dominance? What current adaptive equipment is available to the patient at home, and can it still be utilized based on patient’s current functioning? Document both high-tech  and low-tech adaptations and equipment. What was patient’s prior skill status in terms of independence with ADLs? Is the patient attending school?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives (caregivers, etc.). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? Are family/caretakers supportive?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.)  Considering the many types of clinical presentations that occur with UE amputation, assessment will be highly individualized and modified based upon the patient’s level of amputation, stage in the healing process, pain level, and social/emotional functioning
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Anthropometric characteristics –Record residual limb length and circumference using tape measure or digit circumference gauge(3) –Document the shape of the residual limb –Document presence of scar tissue –Measure swelling with circumferential or volumetric measurements
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assistive and adaptive devices –Did the patient use any assistive or adaptive devices prior to the amputation? If so, they will likely need to be altered –Document use of and level of independence with adaptive equipment utilized pre/post surgery but prior to prosthetic development –If the incision has healed, a prosthesis has been fabricated, and training has begun, document present level of independence with the current device –Document any other adaptive equipment or assistive technology that may be used in conjunction with the prosthetic device
relevant tests and measures.balance: Balance –Complete a gross evaluation of balance reactions in sit and stance with and without prosthesis –Evaluate static and dynamic balance during ADL tasks and functional mobility –Upper limb loss has been associated with an increased risk for falls(24)
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Evaluate pulse and vital signs regularly pre/during/post activity
Monitor breathing to assist with determining fatigue and endurance levels
Observe overall endurance through general activities
The 6-minute  walk for distance test (6MWT) can be used to assess endurance
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Circulation –Evaluate temperature of limb –Note any hair growth Cranial/peripheral nerve integrity –Evaluate sensation, refer to sensory testing section below –When amputation has occurred as a result of trauma, the brachial plexus may have been injured(2) Ergonomics/body mechanics –Assess patient’s body mechanics during transitional movements and functional activities(2) –Patient may benefit from a workstation evaluation if returning to work Functional mobility  (including transfers, etc.) –Evaluate level of independence during transfers and bed mobility; utilize FIM for objective measurement
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Gait/locomotion –Evaluate gait and note any deviations –The Dynamic Gait Index (DGI) can be used to evaluate safety during ambulation –Does the patient use an ambulatory device? Does the amputation affect the use of it?Is there any laxity noted in joints proximal to the amputation? Any restrictions? Motor function (motor control/tone/learning) –Document whether affected limb is the dominant side –Assess motor control of uninvolved limb as indicated –Document any abnormal muscle tone –The Southampton Hand Assessment Procedure (SHAP)(9) is a validated test used to assess the effectiveness of an upper limb prosthesis -Test involves manipulating 6 abstract objects and 14 objects used in performance of ADLs –The Assessment of Capacity for Myoelectric Control (ACMC) is an observation-based  clinical tool that evaluates ability to control a myoelectric prosthetic hand during bimanual activities(9) -Researchers in Sweden recommend using 6 standardized activities that function similarly across both prosthetic sides and both sexes –Activities Measure for Upper-Limb  Amputees (AM-ULA)(9,15,23)  –University of New Brunswick (UNB) Test of Prosthetic Function for Unilateral Amputees(15,23) –Assess coordination as appropriate using a test such as the Jebsen-Taylor  Hand Function Test(9,23) or the Box and Block Test(23) –Assess motor strategies used to accomplish functional tasks such as reach and grasp -Loss of voluntary degrees of freedom (e.g., distal rotation) during use of an upper limb prosthesis forces the individual to use compensatory motor strategies to accomplish functional tasks
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Muscle strength –Use a dynamometer or a pinch meter to assess grip strength –Complete a formal strength assessment with manual muscle testing; include the residual limb, unaffected UE, trunk, and lower extremities(4)
observation inspection palpation includi: Evaluate/document presence of open wounds, or any skin breakdown
Palpate scar tissue areas, commenting on shape, length, and location

Assess for signs of infection, which include: -colored discharge (yellow) -discharge with odor -significant discharge -necrotic tissue -erythema in proximity to the wound -increased warmth around the site
Impairments in circulation may be indicated by coolness around or over the wound
Observe for signs of wound dehiscence, skin breakdown elsewhere, and improper fit of prosthesis
Observe, comment on any areas of swelling
Note presence of stump wrapping and whether it is applied properly
relevant tests and measures.posture: Posture –Complete a full postural assessment; assess posture with/without prosthesis –Document static/dynamic posture in both sitting/standing throughout a variety of tasks with/without prosthesis –Atypical posturing of the shoulder girdle is common in patients after UE amputation. Shoulder elevation on the affected side often is noted(3) –When the muscles that elevate the shoulder girdle are unopposed by the weight of the arm, hiking of the shoulder girdle tends to be inevitable. This can accentuate the cosmetic loss(3) –Assess for scoliosis -Muscular imbalance can result in scoliosis of the spine in adults with UE amputations, although this tends to occur more commonly in patients whose skeleton is still growing(3)
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Range of motion –Complete a formal ROM assessment of the involved limb using goniometry; formally or grossly assess other joints as indicated –Note pain response with any active movement or stretching –Document contractures(4) -In patients with UE amputations, shoulder and elbow flexion contractures often occur, especially with short residual limbs(3) Self-care/activities  of daily living  (objective testing) –If in use, is patient able to independently don and doff compression garments and/or prosthesis? –Document independence with ADLs –Usually, a patient with a(n)(4) -partial hand amputation has loss of grip functions -wrist disarticulation has loss of hand and wrist function -transradial amputation has loss of hand and wrist function, loss of most or all of pronation and supination, and partial loss of elbow flexion and extension -elbow disarticulation has loss of hand and wrist function, pronation, supination, and elbow flexion and extension  -transhumeral amputation has loss of all of the above functions as well as possible loss of shoulder external and internal rotation -shoulder disarticulation has loss of all hand and arm functions -scapulothoracic amputation has loss of all hand, arm, and possibly scapular functions
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Sensory testing –Examine for sensory awareness of the extremity including tactile localization, static and moving stimuli, kinesthetic awareness, one- and two-point  discrimination, sensory discrimination, stereognosis, and light touch –Document phantom limb sensation or any reports of impaired sensation per patient report
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Standardized tests for adults with UE amputations -Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder, and Hand (DASH) Outcome Measure -For additional information on the DASH see  Clinical Review ... Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) Outcome Measure   CINAHL Topic ID number T903177 -QuickDASH(20,23) -Orthotics and Prosthetics User Survey (OPUS)(9,15) -Trinity Amputation and Prosthesis Experience Scales (TAPES)(9) -Patient-Specific  Functional Scale (PSFS)(15) –A vocational assessment and functional capacity evaluation may be appropriate as part of determination of return-to-work status(6) –Clinicians may use specialized tools such as the MyoBoy as part of their evaluation/treatment regimen; functions of the(7) -Isolated muscle training in preparation for a myoelectric prosthetic hand -Evaluating muscle strength -Tracking progress and outcomes
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Arousal, attention, cognition (including memory, problem solving) –Document patient’s ability to communicate and level of arousal, as mental status may be impaired. The Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) can be used –If injury was traumatic, did patient sustain any head trauma? –Depression and/or PTSD may occur and can affect communication and arousal –Obtain results of any testing done by other disciplines (e.g., neuropsychology)

electrotherapy contraindications precaut: Used in close proximity to diathermy treatment
in an area with infection or bleeding
if a tumor or malignancy is present in the area
in the area of a DVT or thrombophlebitis
over the heart, stellate, or cervical ganglia
individuals who cannot communicate effectively (e.g., impaired cognition, language barrier)
Note: Always decrease ultrasound intensity if the patient complains of discomfort
other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols
Consult with surgeon prior to performing massage over areas with skin grafts(4)

Electrotherapy  contraindications/precautions include: (in some cases, when approved by the treating physician , electrotherapy may be used under some of the circumstances listed below when benefits outweigh the perceived risk)(8)
Therapeutic ultrasound  contraindications include; do not use:(8)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Diagnosis/need for treatment Patients commonly need treatment to address pain and edema; diminished ROM, strength, coordination, and sensation; scar tissue management; and prosthesis training for use/care(4) Goals are to allow the patient to return to a level of function with which he or she can participate at home, at work, and in the community as independently as possible with accommodations and use of prosthetic device if prescribed
prognosis: The level of amputation can significantly impact the prognosis, as this directly correlates to the level of function a patient may be able to regain (see Tests and measures , above)(2,21)
Motivation and acceptance are key factors in prosthetic success(9)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines  (4) Driver training specialist Occupational therapist (OT) Physician/surgeon Prosthetist Psychologist Psychiatrist Social worker V ocational counselor Support groups
treatment summary: Prosthetic considerations –The decision regarding whether a prosthesis is appropriate and which prosthesis to select depends on the patient’s age, level of amputation, skin condition and coverage, comorbid medical conditions, cognitive status, and patient’s motivation and goals -Recent advances in prosthetic technology have yielded new options for prostheses for patients with partial hand amputations; however, more research in this area is needed to achieve the best functional outcomes(16) -These patients usually are more challenging for prosthetists and therapists due to such comorbidities as:(16) -hyper-  or hyposensitive tissue  -decreased ROM -adherent scar tissue -decreased circulation -neuromas -burns -The team must also determine how the remaining digits will interact with the mechanical digits and how the alignment of the mechanical digits will affect function -Training begins with pinch and grasp and evolves into higher-level  tasks for ADLs, IADLs, and work and leisure activities

Pre-prosthetic  treatment involves(4) –facilitating patient’s acceptance of limb loss and improvement in psychosocial adjustment –facilitating wound healing and preventing scar adhesions –reducing sensitivity of residual limb with desensitization techniques –improving UE ROM and strength and preventing contractures -Strengthening exercises should be specific to the type of prosthesis that will eventually be used -Strengthening of the shoulder, elbow, and scapular muscles is important for transradial amputations -Strengthening of the shoulder depressors, extensors, and abductors is necessary for patients with transhumeral amputations -Chest expansion exercises are necessary for patients with high-level  amputations –educating the patient regarding skin hygiene and inspection -The patient should be taught to look at the residual limb while performing functional activities, to position the limb carefully while sitting, and to avoid using the limb to test the temperature of water –shaping and sizing the residual limb -An elastic bandage, tubular bandage, or a shrinker sock is used for wrapping -Elastic bandages are applied smoothly and evenly, not too tightly, using a figure-8  method starting from the distal end of the residual limb

The prosthetic program involves(4) –educating the patient regarding: -Residual limb hygiene -The patient should inspect, wash, and pat the residual limb dry and apply antiperspirant deodorant daily -Prosthetic sock hygiene -The sock should be changed daily -Care of prosthesis -The socket should be gently washed and rinsed at night with a mild soap -The patient should follow the manufacturer’s guidelines (e.g., battery charging procedures) -Wearing schedule -Initially, the prosthesis typically is worn for 15 to 30 minutes 3 times per day -If there are no adverse skin reactions the wearing time can be increased by 30 minutes per day, with the patient wearing the prosthesis all day by the end of 1 week -Donning and doffing prosthesis -Coat vs. sweater method(4) -Control training(4) -The patient learns the minimal motions necessary to operate the prosthesis while maintaining proper body mechanics -Therapist should stress joint protection, energy conservation, and work simplification principles and techniques -Use training(4) -Training for grasp and release –functional training

Types of prostheses(4,9) –Body-powered  prosthesis(4,15,18) -Indicated for wrist disarticulation amputations and higher -Activated through muscle and body actions that apply a force to a cable and allow for prehension  -Feedback to the individual occurs through tension on the prosthesis as well as through visual scanning -Less expensive than externally powered prostheses -Lighter than externally powered prostheses -Easy to use -Long-lasting -Precise fit not essential -Reduced instruction time when compared to externally powered prostheses -Able to complete heavy work -Suspension may inflame the axilla -Most common parts of a prosthesis include: -prosthetic sock -Sock composed of knit wool, cotton, or Lycra -Used to absorb perspiration, protect against irritation, and compensate for volume changes in the residual limb, contributing to improved fit and comfort in the socket(4) -There is also a sock called Silo-Liner  made by Silipos that can assist in minimizing hypertrophic scarring(4) -socket -Cast mold is used to fabricate -Assists with a providing an individualized fit for function; should be long enough to be stable but not too long to restrict motion -Single-wall  construction: commonly used with a wrist or elbow disarticulation and requires no shaping(4) -Double-wall  construction: involves an inner wall and an outer wall that are laminated together; inner socket can be flexible to allow for volume and contour changes that occur when the muscles contract and relax(4) -harness -Worn around the back and opposite shoulder to fasten the socket and prosthesis to the limb -Most common harness is of figure-8 construction -cable -Attaches the harness to the terminal device; specific upper body movements create tension on the cables to operate the prosthesis(4) -terminal device -Mechanism on the prosthesis that achieves grasp/release of items for functional tasks, or can stabilize an object -Either hook or hand style -May have voluntary opening (VO) or voluntary closing (VC) design (26) -Most body-powered  prosthesis users choose the VO design -Advantages of the VO include once an object has been grasped the user does not need to exert force to maintain that grasp – a spring provides the force to hold the object -In contrast, with the VC design the pinch force is generated by the user. The user can apply varying forces for varying tasks, but must maintain the force throughout the task, which can cause fatigue -wrist unit -Attaches the terminal device to the socket -Allows for forearm supination and pronation -elbow unit(4) -Allows for 5˚ to 135˚ of flexion -Can lock in various positions, can lock internally or externally, and may include a lift assist -transradial hinges(4) -On each side of the elbow of a transradial prosthesis; stabilize and properly align the prosthesis for optimal distribution of stress on the limb -prosthesis for partial hand amputations(16) -Passive functional devices -Opposition posts -Task-specific  devices  -Mechanical fingers -Operate through the harnessing of proximal joints and anatomy -The majority of persons with UE amputations are reported to prefer a cable-operated,  body-powered prosthesis over a myoelectric prosthesis(18) –Externally powered(9) -Feedback to the individual typically is through vision alone -Newer versions may allow for 3 different hand grips -May provide the patient with increased pinch strength, complete wrist rotation, and ability to complete ADLswithout concern over mechanical disadvantage (as would be the concern with body-powered  prostheses) -Electrically powered terminal device prehensors -Operates through myoelectric or switch control -Digital control: constant speed -Proportional control: variable speed in which the speed and pinch force increase in proportion to the intensity of the muscle contraction -prosthetic hands -Single-joint  myoelectric prosthetic hands(26) -Myoelectrically controlled multiarticulated hands -Have the ability to fold around objects and perform various grip types, which make them more like human hands -i-LIMB -Bebionic hand -i-LIMB  Pulse -externally powered partial-hand prosthesis(16) -Provide multiarticulating motorized digits that are powered by batteries -These devices provide the highest grasp and pinch forces and can simulate the pinch and grip patterns of the human hand -i-LIMB  digits -electric hooks -electric elbows –Passive (cosmetic)(9) –Hybrid(9) – A combination of myoelectric (e.g., for hand function) and body-powered  (for shoulder and elbow movement) –DEKA Arm – a precommercial upper-limb  prosthetic prototype engineered to provide the potential for significantly greater upper-limb  function than devices currently on the market (currently, there are no devices that allow for more than one movement at a time, and there are no powered prosthetic shoulders on the market)(15) -Allows up to 10˚ of powered movement and 6 pre-programmed  hand grips -The powered elbow provides flexion, extension, and humeral rotation -The powered wrist flexes, extends, supinates, pronates, and medially and laterally deviates -The device is operated by a combination of methods, including foot controls, optional EMG controls, pressure switches, or other commonly available prosthetic input elements -The DEKA Arm that includes a powered shoulder includes end-point  control that allows simultaneous control of multiple arm joints -Researchers who conducted a quasi-experimental  study in the United States found that users were able to perform more activities with the DEKA Arm than with their current prosthesis and had less difficulty performing self-selected activities, but in general dexterity was equivalent or diminished across all groups except for those using the powered shoulder, who experienced improved dexterity(15) –Activity-specific  prostheses(9) -Include recreational prostheses and those designed to facilitate work tasks or ADLs -Examples include prostheses for rock climbing or violin playing -Most have limited utility but are very effective for specific tasks –Future directions(22) -Given the cost of myoelectric prostheses, there are many patients who could benefit from one but are not able to afford one  -Researchers in the United States conducted a pilot study to compare the utility of a commercially available myoelectric prosthesis to one created with a 3D printer. The quasi-experimental  study was done using able-bodied  subjects fit with the prostheses via a custom attachment -The results of the study showed that the subjects performed better on the Box and Block Test using the commercially available prosthesis, but were able to perform the test with the significantly less expensive, 3D-printer-created  prosthesis -Based on the study, the authors conclude that with additional refinement and development, clinical application of 3D printer prosthetics may be a viable option in the future .
